title: 111_hr2123
content:
The Act may be cited as the "1863 Gettysburg Campaign Act". The Congress acknowledges the significance of the 1863 invasion of Pennsylvania and the Battle of Gettysburg in the American Civil War. President Abraham Lincoln's Gettysburg Address highlighted the war's importance in relation to the American Revolution. The Army Heritage Center Foundation collaborates with the United States Army to maintain the Army Heritage and Education Center in Carlisle, Pennsylvania, which is a leading center for studying the role of individual soldiers in national defense. The Center's Civil War collection is highly regarded nationwide. The Army Heritage Center Foundation aims to honor soldiers' service and sacrifice, preserve their memories through artifact collections, and educate the public. Their goal is to promote appreciation for the sacrifices made by American soldiers and their families to safeguard the nation's freedoms. The Foundation will fund and construct the public components of the Army Heritage and Education Center, focusing on providing support once construction is complete. The Gettysburg Foundation supports the Gettysburg National Military Park by operating the Museum and Visitor Center, funding preservation efforts, displaying the Cyclorama painting, and educating visitors about the significance of the Battle of Gettysburg in the context of the American Civil War. The Army Heritage Center Foundation and the Gettysburg Foundation are nonprofit organizations dependent on member funds, donations, and grants to support the Gettysburg National Military Park and the Army Heritage and Education Center. The Gettysburg Foundation is the official partner of the National Military Park, while the Army Heritage Center Foundation is recognized as the lead agency supporting the development of the Army Heritage and Education Center. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins in commemoration of the 1863 Invasion of Pennsylvania and the Battle of Gettysburg. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins in commemoration of the 1863 Invasion of Pennsylvania and the Battle of Gettysburg. The half dollar coins will weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and be minted to specific specifications. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall commemorate the Gettysburg campaign and President Lincoln's Gettysburg Address with specific motifs. Each coin will include a value designation, the year "2013", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall commemorate the Gettysburg campaign and President Lincoln's Gettysburg Address with specific motifs. The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Secretary of the Army, the Secretary of the Interior, and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Mint facilities will be used to strike these coins during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2013.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges: $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half dollar coin. Surcharges received will be split between the Army Heritage Center Foundation and the Gettysburg Foundation. Both foundations will be audited for the amounts received. The Act mandates surcharges on all coins minted, with specific amounts allocated to the Army Heritage Center Foundation and the Gettysburg Foundation. However, there is a limitation on the number of commemorative coin programs that can be issued in a calendar year to avoid exceeding the annual issuance limit. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide guidance on this limitation.
